**Stormbringer**, often nicknamed **Stormy** by players, is an [intelligent](/wiki/Intelligent "Intelligent") [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is [chaotic](/wiki/Chaotic "Chaotic")-aligned, and its [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") is a [runesword](/wiki/Runesword "Runesword").

[ ]

## Generation

Stormbringer can appear as a [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift") for chaotic characters, and is also the chaotic [crowning](/wiki/Crowning "Crowning") gift. It is not randomly generated, since runeswords are not generated outside of [wishes](/wiki/Wish "Wish") or [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Description

Stormbringer grants +1d5 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") and deals an extra +d2 in bonus [damage](/wiki/Damage "Damage") to monsters without [drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance") - the life-draining further reduces the target's level by 1, and lowers their current and maximum HP appropriately (usually by 1d8).[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) The wielder will then be healed for half of the reduced HP, rounded down (roughly 2 HP on average). Stormbringer is also [bloodthirsty](/wiki/Bloodthirsty "Bloodthirsty"), attacking peaceful monsters and pets without confirmation if you attempt to move onto their square while wielding it.

Stormbringer also confers [drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance") when wielded, and is itself immune to [drain life](/wiki/Drain_life "Drain life") and other similar attacks[\[3\]](#cite_note-3). Levels drained from [trolls](/wiki/Troll "Troll") with Stormbringer are permanently lost; levels drained from the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") will be restored when he next revives. The [Riders](/wiki/Riders "Riders") preserve their HP values at time of death and retain it for their revival, including any HP loss incurred from Stormbringer.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

## Strategy

Stormbringer is among the most desirable chaotic artifacts in the game - [twoweaponing](/wiki/Twoweaponing "Twoweaponing") Stormbringer with a [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver") weapon is particularly effective, since many drain-resistant monsters (including monsters with draining attacks) are *also* silver haters. Chaotic [Rangers](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger") will most appreciate an effective melee option, especially if they have not mapped out [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") to use their arrows reliably, while chaotic [Priests](/wiki/Priest "Priest") can pair it with their [quest artifact](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact"), [the Mitre of Holiness](/wiki/The_Mitre_of_Holiness "The Mitre of Holiness"), to blunt damage from drain-resistant [demons](/wiki/M2_DEMON "M2 DEMON") and [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead").

However, those seeking to use Stormbringer as their main weapon should avoid using pets if possible, as even a careful player may accidentally attack a pet with it - if you elect to keep a pet on hand, you may consider unwielding Stormbringer or switching to a secondary weapon when not in combat, especially when dealing with [aligned priests](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest") or [shopkeepers](/wiki/Shopkeepers "Shopkeepers"). Additionally, if any pets you plan to keep are not drain resistant, they should ideally have high enough health to withstand accidental hits and a way to increase their [tameness](/wiki/Tameness "Tameness") to prevent them turning on you.

If you need to reduce the enchantment of Stormbringer (e.g., to reduce from +6 to +5 for an attempt to get to +7), the drain life spell will not work, but [engraving](/wiki/Engraving "Engraving") still does.

As most hostile spellcasters are either drain resistant or else possess high [monster magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)"), Stormbringer can bypass the latter group's defenses to reduce their level where the drain life spell cannot (though it will often kill non-resistant monsters before the effects become noticable). Famine and Pestilence may also be ideal targets for the weapon in some situations, since they revive with their current max HP rather than their original base HP.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

It is extremely unwise to use the \_ (auto run) command if you have Stormbringer wielded, especially in areas filled with peacefuls. You will automatically attempt to displace any peaceful creatures you walk into, including creatures such as the [watch captain](/wiki/Watch_captain "Watch captain") or a co-aligned [titan](/wiki/Titan "Titan"). This will result in you attempting to attack them, immediately aggroing them and potentially causing your death. The use of pets on the level where you plan to use the auto run command should be avoided for the same reason.

### Forcing Stormbringer

Elven priests and elven rangers can arrange for their first [sacrifice](/wiki/Sacrifice "Sacrifice") gift to be Stormbringer - since it will always be [co-aligned](/wiki/Co-aligned "Co-aligned") and will not hate your race, only [Sting](/wiki/Sting "Sting") and [Orcrist](/wiki/Orcrist "Orcrist") compete with Stormbringer, and both of them can be #[named](/wiki/Name "Name"). In rare cases, if Stormbringer has already been generated on a bones level, this will preclude sacrifice gifts altogether. A [helm of opposite alignment](/wiki/Helm_of_opposite_alignment "Helm of opposite alignment") can remedy the situation.

Theoretically, almost anyone could get a guaranteed Stormbringer if polymorphed into elven form and converted to chaotic from a helm of opposite alignment - the exception is if you started as chaotic *and* your role gets a guaranteed first sacrifice gift. However, this is very much a [stupid ascension trick](/wiki/Stupid_ascension_trick "Stupid ascension trick") rather than practical advice.

## History

Stormbringer is introduced in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") and earlier versions, Stormbringer was one of many ways a player could enact [drain for gain](/wiki/Drain_for_gain "Drain for gain").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Stormbringer](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stormbringer "wikipedia:Stormbringer")***

Stormbringer is a weapon that appears in a number of fantasy stories from author [Michael Moorcock](/wiki/People_of_secondary_interest_to_NetHack#Michael_Moorcock "People of secondary interest to NetHack") featuring Elric of Melniboné. Stormbringer is a cursed daemon sword with a will of its own and a hunger for souls, which it instills into Elric and frequently torments him with by using the bloodlust to make him kill his friends and loved ones; Elric hates the sword, but is too dependent on its power. It physically appears as a black sword with runes engraved deep in the blade, reflected by its appearance as a runesword in *NetHack*.

## Messages

- Your bloodthirsty blade attacks!

  You moved into a peaceful or tame monster while wielding Stormbringer, causing you to attack them.

- The black blade draws the life from \<monster>!

  You used Stormbringer to attack a non-drain resistant monster.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), there is a runesword in the [Lawful Quest](/wiki/Lawful_Quest "Lawful Quest"), which has a 5% probability of being Stormbringer if it hasn't already been generated.

Where most [artifact weapons in SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM_artifacts "SLASH'EM artifacts") do their maximum damage bonus instead of a random number, Stormbringer's case is somewhat more complex - it has a regular damage bonus and a level-drain damage bonus, and rather than doing maximum damage on both, it does +2 for the regular damage bonus and continues to do 1d8 for the level-drain bonus, making it do on average only 0.5 damage points more than vanilla.

This makes it considerably weaker than other artifacts such as [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur") and [Snickersnee](/wiki/Snickersnee "Snickersnee") compared to vanilla, and dramatically weaker than the more powerful chaotic SLASH'EM artifacts such as the [Bat from Hell](/wiki/Bat_from_Hell "Bat from Hell"), [Doomblade](/wiki/Doomblade "Doomblade"), and [Serpent's Tongue](/wiki/Serpent%27s_Tongue "Serpent's Tongue"). However, it does enjoy a full +5 to hit as well as the hit point gain bonus, making it a significant boon in SLASH'EM's challenging early game. Additionally, its [drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance") makes it a useful alternate weapon when facing off against monsters with a [wand of draining](/wiki/Wand_of_draining "Wand of draining") and late-game [deep dragons](/wiki/Deep_dragon "Deep dragon").

While SLASH'EM allows [twoweaponing](/wiki/Twoweapon "Twoweapon") with two artifacts, extrinsics granted by wielding the artifacts are only available for the artifact wielded in the primary hand - Stormbringer should be your primary weapon if you plan to utilize its drain resistance while two-weaponing. Stormbringer's bloodthirsty properties are also active even while in the off-hand. ("The black blade will not be thwarted!")

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), Stormbringer can be [invoked](/wiki/Invoked "Invoked") to [scare](/wiki/Scare "Scare") monsters.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), Stormbringer can be [forged](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") together with [Werebane](/wiki/Werebane "Werebane") to create [Shadowblade](/wiki/Shadowblade "Shadowblade"), an artifact [athame](/wiki/Athame "Athame").

## Encyclopedia entry

There were sounds in the distance, incongruent with the sounds of even this nameless, timeless sea: thin sounds, agonized and terrible, for all that they remained remote - yet the ship followed them, as if drawn by them; they grew louder - pain and despair were there, but terror was predominant.  
Elric had heard such sounds echoing from his cousin Yyrkoon's sardonically named 'Pleasure Chambers' in the days before he had fled the responsibilities of ruling all that remained of the old Melnibonean Empire. These were the voices of men whose very souls were under siege; men to whom death meant not mere extinction, but a continuation of existence, forever in thrall to some cruel and supernatural master. He had heard men cry so when his salvation and his nemesis, his great black battle-blade Stormbringer, drank their souls.

\[ The Lands Beyond the World, by Michael Moorcock ]

The [[Riders]] preserve their HP values at time of death and retain it for their revival, including any HP loss incurred from Stormbringer.{{refsrc|src/zap.c|606|version=NetHack 3.6.6}} ==Strategy== Stormbringer is among the most desirable chaotic artifacts in the game - [[twoweaponing]] Stormbringer with a [[silver]] weapon is particularly effective, since many drain-resistant monsters (including monsters with draining attacks) are ''also'' silver haters. Chaotic [[Ranger]]s will most appreciate an effective melee option, especially if they have not mapped out [[Gehennom]] to use their arrows reliably, while chaotic [[Priest]]s can pair it with their [[quest artifact]], [[the Mitre of Holiness]], to blunt damage from drain-resistant [[M2_DEMON|demons]] and [[undead]]. However, those seeking to use Stormbringer as their main weapon should avoid using pets if possible, as even a careful player may accidentally attack a pet with it - if you elect to keep a pet on hand, you may consider unwielding Stormbringer or switching to a secondary weapon when not in combat, especially when dealing with [[aligned priest]]s or [[shopkeepers]]. Additionally, if any pets you plan to keep are not drain resistant, they should ideally have high enough health to withstand accidental hits and a way to increase their [[tameness]] to prevent them turning on you. If you need to reduce the enchantment of Stormbringer (e.g., to reduce from +6 to +5 for an attempt to get to +7), the drain life spell will not work, but [[engraving]] still does. As most hostile spellcasters are either drain resistant or else possess high [[magic resistance (monster)|monster magic resistance]], Stormbringer can bypass the latter group's defenses to reduce their level where the drain life spell cannot (though it will often kill non-resistant monsters before the effects become noticable). Famine and Pestilence may also be ideal targets for the weapon in some situations, since they revive with their current max HP rather than their original base HP. {{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|It is extremely unwise to use the _ (auto run) command if you have Stormbringer wielded, especially in areas filled with peacefuls. You will automatically attempt to displace any peaceful creatures you walk into, including creatures such as the [[watch captain]] or a co-aligned [[titan]]. This will result in you attempting to attack them, immediately aggroing them and potentially causing your death. The use of pets on the level where you plan to use the auto run command should be avoided for the same reason.}} ===Forcing Stormbringer=== Elven priests and elven rangers can arrange for their first [[sacrifice]] gift to be Stormbringer - since it will always be [[co-aligned]] and will not hate your race, only [[Sting]] and [[Orcrist]] compete with Stormbringer, and both of them can be #[[name]]d. In rare cases, if Stormbringer has already been generated on a bones level, this will preclude sacrifice gifts altogether. A [[helm of opposite alignment]] can remedy the situation. Theoretically, almost anyone could get a guaranteed Stormbringer if polymorphed into elven form and converted to chaotic from a helm of opposite alignment - the exception is if you started as chaotic ''and'' your role gets a guaranteed first sacrifice gift. In [[NetHack 3.4.3]] and earlier versions, Stormbringer was one of many ways a player could enact [[drain for gain]]. ==Origin== {{Wikipedia|Stormbringer}} Stormbringer is a weapon that appears in a number of fantasy stories from author [[People of secondary interest to NetHack#Michael Moorcock|Michael Moorcock]] featuring Elric of Melniboné. Stormbringer is a cursed daemon sword with a will of its own and a hunger for souls, which it instills into Elric and frequently torments him with by using the bloodlust to make him kill his friends and loved ones; Elric hates the sword, but is too dependent on its power. It physically appears as a black sword with runes engraved deep in the blade, reflected by its appearance as a runesword in ''NetHack''. ==Messages== {{message|Your bloodthirsty blade attacks!|You moved into a peaceful or tame monster while wielding Stormbringer, causing you to attack them.}} {{message|The black blade draws the life from !|You used Stormbringer to attack a non-drain resistant monster.}} ==Variants== ===SLASH'EM=== In [[SLASH'EM]], there is a runesword in the [[Lawful Quest]], which has a 5% probability of being Stormbringer if it hasn't already been generated. Where most [[SLASH'EM artifacts|artifact weapons in SLASH'EM]] do their maximum damage bonus instead of a random number, Stormbringer's case is somewhat more complex - it has a regular damage bonus and a level-drain damage bonus, and rather than doing maximum damage on both, it does +2 for the regular damage bonus and continues to do 1d8 for the level-drain bonus, making it do on average only 0.5 damage points more than vanilla. This makes it considerably weaker than other artifacts such as [[Excalibur]] and [[Snickersnee]] compared to vanilla, and dramatically weaker than the more powerful chaotic SLASH'EM artifacts such as the [[Bat from Hell]], [[Doomblade]], and [[Serpent's Tongue]]. However, it does enjoy a full +5 to hit as well as the hit point gain bonus, making it a significant boon in SLASH'EM's challenging early game. Additionally, its [[drain resistance]] makes it a useful alternate weapon when facing off against monsters with a [[wand of draining]] and late-game [[deep dragon]]s. While SLASH'EM allows [[twoweapon]]ing with two artifacts, extrinsics granted by wielding the artifacts are only available for the artifact wielded in the primary hand - Stormbringer should be your primary weapon if you plan to utilize its drain resistance while two-weaponing. Stormbringer's bloodthirsty properties are also active even while in the off-hand. ("The black blade will not be thwarted!") ===SpliceHack=== In [[SpliceHack]], Stormbringer can be [[invoked]] to [[scare]] monsters. ===EvilHack=== In [[EvilHack]], Stormbringer can be [[Forge (dungeon feature)|forged]] together with [[Werebane]] to create [[Shadowblade]], an artifact [[athame]]. ==Encyclopedia entry== {{encyclopedia| There were sounds in the distance, incongruent with the sounds of even this nameless, timeless sea: thin sounds, agonized and terrible, for all that they remained remote - yet the ship followed them, as if drawn by them; they grew louder - pain and despair were there, but terror was predominant. Elric had heard such sounds echoing from his cousin Yyrkoon's sardonically named 'Pleasure Chambers' in the days before he had fled the responsibilities of ruling all that remained of the old Melnibonean Empire. These were the voices of men whose very souls were under siege; men to whom death meant not mere extinction, but a continuation of existence, forever in thrall to some cruel and supernatural master. He had heard men cry so when his salvation and his nemesis, his great black battle-blade Stormbringer, drank their souls. |[ The Lands Beyond the World, by Michael Moorcock ] }} ==References== {{nethack-366}} [[Category:Artifact weapons]]
